newsitem.title: GUATEMALA: Six firms interested in Guatemala railroad sale.
newsitem.headline: Six firms interested in Guatemala railroad sale.

text.p: Six international firms have begun the bidding process for rights to run Guatemala's railroad, an official said Wednesday.

Canada's Canarail, Germany's D.E. Consult, U.S. Railroad Development Corporation from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, Spain's Renfe, Ferrocarriles Nacionales de Mexico and Argentina's Benito Roggio e Hijos, S.A. have picked up bidding instructions, Andres Porras of the Guatemalan Railroad Company (FEGUA) told Reuters.

The winning railroad company will not have to make a downpayment for the concession, but must cover the total investment to rebuild and repair Guatemala's 512 miles of rotting, defunct railway. The government will not charge a percentage on annual income.
Guatemala's railway system includes one Atlantic-Pacific railroad line that runs from Puerto Barrios on the East coast via Guatemala City to Tecun Uman at the Mexican border.
A connecting line travels to the El Salvador border, and two other lines run from west coast ports to Escuintla and Retalhuleu.

Each bidder must submit a technical and a financial proposal of what it will pay the government annually for the concession, Porras said. The economic bids are due May 15 and will be opened after technical bids are reviewed with a decision due June 1.
The government estimates the railroad could generate 1,000 jobs and could move up to two million metric tonnes of cargo a year in five years, he added.
Porras said banana, cement, and construction companies have all expressed interest in the rehabilitation of the railway.
